title: Before July 2017, will the New Development Bank issue any rupee-denominated bonds?
preds: Updating for the passage of time.

The New Development Bank floated by the BRICS’ consortium plans to issue two bonds this year – a yuan denominated bond and a rupee denominated one – worth around 3 billion yuan and Rs 3,000 crore, respectively. Officials said the bonds would be brought out after June. “In all probability there would be a Rs 3,000-crore bond issuance by the New Development Bank (NDB),” finance ministry officials said. The rupee bond will be the first such issue by the bank. The bank also has plans to float a rouble bond early next year, said officials. http://www.ndb.int/medias/brics-bank-launch-twin-bonds/ After June hardly leaves any time for the bond issue to be concluded before Jul 1.

See @Khalid
Going to take a beating on this one! Focussed too much on whether it would happen and not enough on timeline.

Dropping to zero because they have stated new bonds will be issues in the second half of the year http://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/30/reuters-america-update-1-brics-development-bank-to-issue-up-to-500-million-in-masala-bonds.html

Brics development bank chief K.V. Kamath says the bank plans to raise up to $500 million via rupee-denominated masala bonds in the second half of the year "New Delhi: The New Development Bank set up by the Brics group of major emerging economies plans to raise up to $500 million via rupee-denominated masala bonds in the second half of the year, the bank’s president, K.V. Kamath, said on Thursday.
“We would be ready with the masala bond in local currency in the second half,” Kamath told Reuters in an interview in New Delhi. http://www.livemint.com/Industry/08hlIUpKTYvZYHwfMU8bzH/Brics-development-bank-to-issue-up-to-500-million-in-masala.html COMMENT - This question closes on 01 July, effectively before the "second half" of the year.

”We would be ready with the masala bond in local currency in the second half,” Kamath told Reuters in an interview in New Delhi. “Thereafter, in sequence, we will look at the other markets as opportunities open up.”
http://www.ndb.int/medias/brics-development-bank-issue-500-million-masala-bonds-reuters/ Given that it was initially in the 1st quarter, now July is pushing it too close. 1 July is the date for this question.

Major reversal as no news, looks like later in the year
http://in.reuters.com/article/india-brics-development-bank-idINKBN1720C9

Running out of time.  An outfit like this can't just wake up one morning and issue bonds; there are technical and--probably more important and complicated--political considerations that need to be dealt with ahead of issue.  @Raahul_Kumar Reuters link sounds like fall or even winter timeline.

The New Development Bank set up by the BRICS group of emerging economies plans to fund 15 infrastructure projects in member countries worth upto $3 billion this year, the bank's president, K.V. Kamath, said on Thursday. The bank also plans to raise $300 million to $500 million in rupee-denominated bonds, called "masala" bonds, in the second half of the year, Kamath told Reuters in an interview in New Delhi.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-india-brics-idUSKBN1711LV?il=0 Great Kamath, don't give us an exact timetable or anything. I love guessing. Not confident at all it will happen by July, given the vagueness.
Announcement at AGM? which is in New Delhi??

Appetite for Masala Bonds grows
https://www.dlapiper.com/en/hongkong/insights/publications/2017/03/appetite-for-masala-bonds-grows/ Notwithstanding the complete lack of communication from the NDB and absolutely no clear indication of a timetable, a Masala bond release is fairly easy today. 
Can't see why the NDB would have an issue when all other banks have already done it.
No news items after bonds from the NDB. 1st quarter target doesn't seem likely to be met, lucky time open till July.

More evidence that this is an "all hat-no cattle" theme  link here http://asia.nikkei.com/Markets/Commodities/New-Delhi-struggles-with-wheat-tariffs-dilemma-as-prices-fall?n_cid=NARAN11&utm_source=NAR%20Newsletter&utm_campaign=RN%20Free%20newsletter&utm_medium=daily%20newsletter%20free&utm_content=article%20link

Probably going to happen, but not nearly soon enough.  Going in full reverse on this one.  
http://www.livemint.com/Industry/YfZrBKSXfOzEKynXLrPlrL/NDB-plans-to-issue-masala-bonds.html

Correcting earlier forecast. The most recent report I can find was back in October 2016, when the NDB President said the target was the first quarter of 2017. That is now looking unlikely, but there remains enough time till the end of June for an issue.

"After IFC and ADB, the BRICS grouping-promoted New Development Bank (NDB) is also bullish on masala bonds and may hit the market with the maiden issue by December, its president K.V. Kamath has said. http://www.livemint.com/Industry/YfZrBKSXfOzEKynXLrPlrL/NDB-plans-to-issue-masala-bonds.html Thanks to @Anneinak for the link. When the NDB president himself says "by December", before July can almost certainly be ruled out.
EDIT - Note Anneinak's correction, pointing out that December in the article was December 2016.
Last year, NDB was saying it would be first quarter 2017. Now they're saying December.

http://www.livemint.com/Industry/YfZrBKSXfOzEKynXLrPlrL/NDB-plans-to-issue-masala-bonds.html It sounds to me that the maiden issue won't be until about December. EDIT:  Oops.  The article was from last May, so the December mentioned was last December.

The bank has stated they will issue Rupee denominated bonds this year, it is just a question of when. Given that the first bond issue occurred in July last year, I am inclined to think they will follow a similar schedule. However, it is equally possible that the bank, having now done one bond issue, will have worked out some kinks and will do it faster this year. So 33% that it happens before July, and it's too bad this question doesn't have a longer time frame.

Bank has confirmed that Rupee denominated bonds will be sold in 2017. But the timing has not been made clear. 
Since Yuan denominated bonds were issued 'in' July 2016, this could literally go down to the wire.

The New Development Bank (NDB) set up by the BRICS - Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa - will raise funds by issuing rupee-denominated bonds in India.
http://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/02/reuters-america-brics-bank-to-lend-between-25-3-bln-in-2017--china-daily.html

http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/bonds/rbi-allows-multilateral-agencies-to-invest-in-masala-bonds/articleshow/57190529.cms ". . . the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has allowed multilateral and regional financial institutions to invest in rupee denominated bonds listed abroad popularly known as masala bonds.  . . . As a result, agencies like the Asian Development Bank and the BRICS led New Development Bank can also invest in these bonds. 
~~~~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Question.  (I know nothing about international banking):  how hard is it go from buying bonds to issuing them?  I'm guessing buying and selling are totally different, and that the gap is huge.  Please enlighten me.

RBI allows multilateral agencies to invest in masala bonds "In order to provide more choices of investors to Indian entities issuing rupee denominated bonds abroad, it has been decided to also permit multilateral and regional financial institutions where India is a member country, to invest in these rupee denominated bonds," RBI said. As a result, agencies like the Asian Development Bank and the BRICS led New Development Bank can also invest in these bonds.
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/bonds/rbi-allows-multilateral-agencies-to-invest-in-masala-bonds/articleshow/57190529.cms This means this forecast will probably close any day now.

1.Indian companies spice things up in Singapore with masala bonds
Several rupee-denominated bonds have listed on the Singapore Exchange in the past year
http://www.tnp.sg/news/singapore/indian-companies-spice-things-singapore-masala-bonds An option besides just London, but so many other world financial centres are still missing. Why?
Investors can be located anywhere in the world, and so rupee bonds must be available to purchase from anywhere as well. http://www.lseg.com/sites/default/files/content/documents/20170105%20Masala%20Bonds%20Presentation_1.pdf
http://www.longfinance.net/images/GFCI18_23Sep2015.pdf 2.Independent research provider CreditSights has said banks will have to raise 800 billion rupees in equity capital over the next two years to meet Basel III requirements. State-owned banks have been finding it hard to sell shares as investors have demanded steep discounts. As a result, most of these issues will involve AT1 bonds. Foreign institutional investors also welcomed the extension of the concessional 5 percent withholding tax until 2020 on sovereign rupee bonds. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-india-budget-privatisation-idUSKBN15L06M

Sharing my communication with the NDB: Sir,  When might the bank issue rupee-denominated bonds? Reply:  
Thank you for your letter and your interest in the NDB.
The NDB is considering to issue rupee-denominated bonds in 2017. The timing and parameters of the issue will be determined by market conditions and liquidity requirements of the Bank. Best regards,
Alexey Kosarev
Consultant, Corporate Communication
New Development Bank 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I am guessing that issuing rupee-denominated bonds is not something that a bank can decide to do today and then issue tomorrow.  The lack of more specific information suggests to me that this won't happen before July.
I'm giving up on this happening in this time-frame.  I'm reading that the NDB may need to become rated first.
running out of time and interest, i think
Doesn't seem a good time to hold rupee debt, and therefore also not to issue it of you don't have to.  (If people are betting on the rupee to slide in value, are they rupee slippers?)

"Populist" Modi regime admits "demonitisation" policy has not been successful. Companies can now raise funds in the local bond market at cheaper costs, after the move sparked a flood of canceled cash into banks that have plowed the money into debt securities. Investors also profited as rupee corporate bonds had their best month in more than three years in November, amid the worst losses for global debt in a quarter of a century. Modi needs companies to put to work the more than 8 trillion rupees ($117 billion) deposited into banks since his attack on corruption began on Nov. 8, to offset any impact on consumer demand in the world’s fastest-growing major economy. Firms from billionaire Kumar Mangalam Birla’s cement unit to the nation’s largest power producer have sold bonds at less than 7 percent for the first time since 2010. “Borrowing from the corporate bond market is a steal right now as demonetization has cut financing costs,” said Dwijendra Srivastava, the Mumbai-based chief investment officer for debt at Sundaram Asset Management Co. “The drop in bond yields will help companies refinance debt, fund capex and make acquisitions at a cheaper rate.” The average yield for three-year AAA corporate notes in India slumped 45 basis points in November, the biggest monthly decline since 2013. The rally contrasts with pain elsewhere. The Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Total Return Index lost 4 percent in November, the worst slump since the gauge’s inception in 1990.Indian businesses have borrowed a record 3.96 trillion rupees from the bond market so far in 2016. “The momentum of higher issuance is likely to continue even next year as bonds offer companies better rates over bank loans,” said Jayen Shah, Mumbai-based head of debt capital markets at IDFC Bank Ltd., who expects the Reserve Bank of India to cut the benchmark rate by 25 basis points this week. “I expect rare and atypical issuers to tap the bond market.”
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-12-04/modi-bucks-global-bond-rout-as-cash-recall-cuts-india-inc-costs

The BRICS group-promoted New Development Bank is looking to raise funds by issuing rupee bonds to domestic investors to minimise currency risks in supporting long gestation infrastructure projects locally, a senior official said on Friday. “We hope to issue, perhaps by the first quarter of 2017, a bond denominated in the rupee,” NDB vice-president and chief risk officer Paulo Nogueira Batista Jr. told media on the sidelines of the BRICS Economic Forum here.
http://indianexpress.com/article/business/business-others/new-development-bank-set-to-tap-rupee-bonds-to-raise-funds-issue-next-year-3082793/ The BRICS-created New Development Bank is to issue the first Indian rupee bond in the first quarter of 2017. GOA (Sputnik) — The BRICS-created New Development Bank (NDB) intends to issue the first Indian rupee bond worth up to $500 million in the first quarter of 2017, NDB President Kundapur Vaman Kamath told Sputnik on Sunday
https://sputniknews.com/asia/201610161046382352-brics-bank-rupee-bond/

After successfully raising 3 billion yuan-denominated bonds, Shanghai-based New Development Bank (NDB) will issue rupee- and rouble-denominated bonds, its vice-president and chief operations officer Xian Zhu said on Thursday. At a session on BRICS Business Forum here, Xian said preparations were underway and the bank had received in-principle approvals from India and Russia. “In the case of India, the signals that we got are for offshore rupee bonds.” He said the bank’s intention was to use the proceeds of the local currency to finance long-term infrastructure bonds.
http://www.ndb.int/New-Development-Bank-plans-rupee-rouble-bonds.php  It is planning a masala bonds issue — where it will raise rupee-denominated debt from international investors — to support Indian lending operations, he said, adding the issue shall take place in the first quarter of 2017.
http://www.ndb.int/NPA-not-an-issue-rate-cuts-to-fetch-Rs-2-5-trillion-gains-K-V-Kamath.php The bank is now seeking to issue rupee-denominated bond in the offshore Indian rupee market, and is expecting to raise 250 million to 500 million U.S. dollars by March 2017, Kamath revealed, adding that work in raising local currency bonds in South Africa and Russia has simultaneously started.
http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-10/17/c_135761091.htm The BRICS-created New Development Bank is to issue the first Indian rupee bond in the first quarter of 2017.
https://sputniknews.com/asia/201610161046382352-brics-bank-rupee-bond/ New Development Bank, formed by five of the world’s biggest emerging markets, plans to sell as much as $500mn worth of offshore rupee bonds next year as the youngest multilateral lender looks to expand its reach.
“We look forward to raising money in most of our member country markets including India through a masala bond issue which could be $250mn-$500mn,” NDB president KV Kamath said in an interview on the sidelines of the Brics summit in Goa, India. “The Indian issue probably will be in the first quarter of next year.”
http://www.gulf-times.com/story/517592/Brics-bank-planning-to-sell-500mn-rupee-bond

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-india-brics-bank-idUSKBN12G04P
No mention of rupee-denominated bonds in this story, but it's not ruled out, either.  India is just about the Last Economy Standing in this group, so they may have more pull than they would have had a few years ago.  Stay tuned.

NDB is now seeking a credit rating from at least two international sovereign rating agencies as it seeks to diversify funding and raise money through innovative instruments such as rupee-denominated masala bonds, NDB CFO Leslie Maasdorp said, in an interview.  "We are looking at the Indian market, both onshore and offshore. From a pricing perspective, offshore masala bond is the most interesting for us right now. We are examining policy conditions that the RBI (Reserve bank of India) has set. We are speaking to the ministry of finance and external affairs and understand the legal framework because we are a multilateral bank and not registered in any single country," Massdorp said. 
http://ndb.int/BRICS-nations-led-New-Development-Bank-to-raise-up-to-3-billion-in-next-3-years.php RBI has liberalized offshore rupee bonds, and many other banks have already made issues, including World Bank,ADB, Canadian province BC, corporations, etc etc.

London Stock Exchange today is proud to welcome another global first, as the Canadian Province of British Columbia becomes the first foreign government entity to issue a Masala bond, choosing London, the global home for Masala bonds, for its listing. The British Columbia bond raised INR 5 billion (c. $75 million) with 6.62 per cent semi-annual yield, securing high quality investor support from across Europe, Asia and America. It is AAA rated by the three major rating agencies and will mature on 9 January 2020.
http://www.lseg.com/resources/media-centre/press-releases/british-columbia-issues-world%E2%80%99s-first-masala-bond-foreign-government-entity-london-stock-exchange Confused and uncertain as to why a Canadian province is raising masala bond money, but the more the merrier.

The original plan was to issue bonds in local currencies. NDB has already issued bonds in  ¥[1], the ₹ bond is next on the agenda[2]. ₽ bonds will be issued by year end[3]. Brasil's real and South African rand bond issues are scheduled for next year. The question allows enough time for even rand bonds to be issued by that date. "The New Development Bank (NDB), an infrastructure-focused lender established by the BRICS emerging economies, plans to issue debt in the local currencies of its five member countries, the bank's president said. Known as the BRICS bank, the NDB is seen by its members as an alternative to the World Bank. Its launch last year follows the establishment of the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB).NDB, run by K.V. Kamath, a former executive of India's largest private lender ICICI Bank, already has $1 billion in capital, which is set to double next year and increase to $50 billion in the future. Kamath said the bank plans to issue a bond worth around 3 billion renminbi ($455.93 million) "in the next four weeks", followed by an issue in India of roughly the same size. "
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-forum-brics-bank-idUSKCN0Z61FF Recent successful issues of rupee bonds by the Asian Development Bank and World Bank and private corporate issuers. "ADB raises Rs 500 cr in rupee-linked bonds
Asian Development Bank said this was its third bond issue in the offshore rupee-linked market, and the second such issue this year."

So far this lot have  been moving fairly deliberately, so this could be a while off.  Or not.

Rupee denominated bonds issued  by  BRICS bank sounds like nice talk. But the purpose of the bank is to counterpoise the dominance of the traditional financial system, and it is precisely that system that dominates the "offshore rupee linked market."  See this link http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/economy/adb-raises-5-b-via-bonds-linked-to-rupee/article8912365.ece The action is at the competing Asian Development Bank, and the bonds, while dominated in Rupee, are settled in US dollar.  The same dollar BRICS want to move way from. Also JP Morgan and CITI control the market.
